ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A great introduction to not only the field of climate history but also so many more facets of human experience, from the knowledge preserved in a Chinese man's diary about rose blossoms to how all of our lives are impacted by chaos theory and fractals
Past interactions between humans and the climate, anthropogenic global warming, critical analyze of scholarly research papers, etc.

I learned a lot about how different climate events affected humans and the environment throughout history. I gained the skill of interpreting scholarly articles and using them to make claims and arguments, both written and spoken.
Through discussions I further developed analysis skills as well as broadened my understanding of human history and environmental history in relation to climate.

I learned about the science behind different climate proxies, how climate has impacted societies throughout history, geoengineering, and volcanic winters. I also developed writing and research skills, mainly through the final paper.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths; great conversation and discussion surrounding the readings each week, interesting selection of readings, variety in how each session went (sometimes just discussions, sometimes student presentations, sometimes a little intro activity)
Weaknesses; none really but could benefit from more of those little intro activities as mentioned to set the mood and get everyone to interact from the start

Strengths: Scope of material you're exposed to (seminar covers so many different fields - physics, chemistry, meteorology, environmental science, human history, etc), engaging discussions that foster participation, interesting readings, very knowledgeable and encouraging instructor.
Weaknesses: Organization/use of Canvas website.
The discussion and presentation mix was a diversified way to design the classes and I found it highly effective. I see no improvements that could be mde for the course.

One strength is the emphasis placed on student participation. Everyone was able to share their thoughts, and this led to very interesting conversations.  One weakness is that I felt some of the readings could have been shortened or otherwise adjusted so that they were more relevant to the class discussion. I also think that some classes would have benefitted from having more structure instead of just being free discussion.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes definitely; although it certainly has some specific focuses, it covers many broad strokes where anyone could find some little interesting niche e.g. the science of isotopic analysis or palynology or chaos theory and human history or even glaciers.
I would recommend this seminar to other first-years as a way of trying something new.
Yes, the course material can be interesting and applicable to students of various majors and backgrounds, the workload is mostly manageable, and the instructor is very helpful.
Absolutely. This was by far the class I looked forward to every week. It was engaging and the material was just so interesting.

I would recommend this class. I thought the content was fascinating. It's the kind of class where you get out what you put in, so I would only recommend this course to a student interested in the topic. I learned a lot about climate history.
